Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration and Refugee Board's refusal to reinstate a withdrawn refugee claim was reasonable under Rule 53
Application_Facts: The applicant withdrew his claim based on advice, then sought reinstatement when circumstances changed
Court_Ruling: The court dismissed the application for judicial review, upholding the Board’s decision
Grounds_for_Claim: New threats emerged after withdrawal of the claim
Applicable_Legislation: Rule 53 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board’s decision denying reinstatement under Rule 53
Application_Basis: Allegation of changed circumstances and request for reinstatement
Evidence_Assessed: Existence of breach of natural justice
Governing_Rule: Rule 53 allows reinstatement if there was a breach of natural justice or it is in the interests of justice
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to show how reinstatement was in the interests of justice
Cause_Description: The applicant withdrew his refugee claim but later sought reinstatement after new threats emerged
Evidence_Assessment: No breach of natural justice found
Decision_Rationale: The Board found no breach of natural justice or substantial defect, and the applicant did not demonstrate that reinstatement was in the interests of justice
